content: Human history began in Africa, with human ancestors evolving into homosapiens around 200,000 years ago. Small bands of modern humans migrated out of Africa 50,000 to 100,000 years ago, becoming ancestors of all human populations. The Bantu people of West Africa expanded their settlement around 2,500-5,000 years ago, becoming the predominant group in sub-Saharan Africa. Nilo-Saharan languages are found in the Sahel grasslands and eastern Africa, with origins possibly in the Nile valley. The Nilo-Saharan languages may have originated in the Nile valley, but the term "Nilotic" is no longer favored due to intermingling with Bantu speakers. Bantu agriculture was not suitable for extreme southern Africa, which continued to be inhabited by the Khoisan people. By 500 BC, the Bantu had mastered iron smelting, leading to successful agriculture and expansion. African farmers were growing a variety of crops, including bananas from contacts with the Indian Ocean region. After 1450 AD, African farmers grew a variety of crops, including grains and bananas from contacts with the Indian Ocean region. They also had cattle, but the tsetse fly limited cattle farming in the central part of the continent. With the discovery of America, they adopted New World crops like maize and peanuts. By 1500, an estimated 47 million Africans lived in farming communities across the continent. In drier regions like Kenya's Rift Valley, some lived pastoral lives, exchanging livestock for grains. Large towns and cities did not develop due to disease-causing organisms unique to Africa. Outside Africa, populations were less affected by these diseases, allowing for easier city development. Loyalties to large ethnic groups were common among Africans. Large settlements in Africa were not developed due to diseases unique to the region, allowing for easier city development outside Africa. Loyalties to large ethnic groups were largely absent in pre-colonial Africa, with loyalties embedded in extended families and clans instead. Powerful individuals or chiefs, known as "big men," exerted influence through marriage ties and control over trade routes. African loyalties were embedded in extended families, clans, and patron-client relationships. Powerful chiefs consolidated authority through conquest and alliance, leading to the development of African kingdoms. Great artistic achievements characterized these kingdoms, such as naturalistic bronze castings in Benin and Congolese masks that inspired modern artists. The peak occurred in the 18th century, with annual totals reaching 100,000. The British parliament ended the trade in 1807, intercepting over 1,600 ships and freeing 160,000 captives. The British parliament voted to end the Indian Ocean slave trade in 1807. Over the next 60 years, the Royal Navy intercepted more than 1,600 ships and freed over 160,000 captives. Despite efforts to stop the trade, many ships evaded patrols, and slavery continued until its abolition in the Americas in the 1850s and 1860s.
